content.title: Meniere Disease
content.summary: Meniere disease is an inner ear disorder characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. It results from endolymphatic hydrops (excess endolymph fluid). Attacks last 20 minutes to 12 hours and recur unpredictably. Management includes dietary sodium restriction, diuretics, and procedures for refractory cases.
key_points: Classic tetrad: Episodic vertigo (20 min-12 hr) + fluctuating hearing loss + tinnitus + aural fullness
Pathophysiology: Endolymphatic hydrops - excess fluid in endolymphatic compartment
Unilateral initially in most; becomes bilateral in 30-50% over time
Low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss early; progresses to all frequencies
Refractory: Intratympanic gentamicin (chemical labyrinthectomy) or surgery
content.statement: Meniere disease is an idiopathic inner ear disorder causing episodic vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and fullness, attributed to endolymphatic hydrops, and managed with salt restriction, diuretics, and interventional procedures for refractory cases.

explanation.intuition: Imagine the inner ear as a water balloon with two fluid compartments. In Meniere's, excess fluid (endolymph) builds up and creates periodic ruptures in the membrane separating these compartments, like pressure waves when a dam bursts. Each rupture causes a vertigo attack, and repeated ruptures progressively damage the hearing and balance organs.
explanation.key_insight: Meniere's causes EPISODIC vertigo (attacks with symptom-free intervals), NOT constant dizziness. The hearing loss FLUCTUATES early in the disease (worse during attacks, improves between) but becomes permanent as the disease progresses. Low-frequency hearing loss is characteristic early.
explanation.technical_details: Endolymphatic hydrops causes distension of Reissner's membrane and ruptures allowing potassium-rich endolymph to mix with perilymph, temporarily paralyzing vestibular and cochlear hair cells. AAO-HNS criteria require ≥2 vertigo episodes (20min-12hr) + audiometrically documented fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss.

definitions_glossary.Meniere_disease: Inner ear disorder with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and fullness
definitions_glossary.endolymphatic_hydrops: Pathological accumulation of endolymph fluid in the membranous labyrinth
definitions_glossary.vertigo: Illusion of rotational movement, distinct from dizziness or lightheadedness
definitions_glossary.tinnitus: Perception of sound (often roaring or hissing) without external source
definitions_glossary.aural_fullness: Sensation of pressure or blockage in the affected ear
definitions_glossary.sensorineural_hearing_loss: Hearing loss from cochlear or auditory nerve dysfunction
definitions_glossary.Tumarkin_drop_attack: Sudden fall without loss of consciousness from otolith dysfunction
definitions_glossary.intratympanic_gentamicin: Aminoglycoside injection destroying vestibular function (chemical labyrinthectomy)
definitions_glossary.intratympanic_steroids: Dexamethasone injections for acute attacks or prevention
definitions_glossary.vestibular_labyrinthectomy: Surgical destruction of vestibular apparatus for intractable vertigo
definitions_glossary.cochlear_implant: Option for patients with profound hearing loss in affected ear

pathophysiology.mechanism: Endolymphatic hydrops causes periodic ruptures of the membranous labyrinth, mixing high-potassium endolymph with perilymph, causing temporary hair cell paralysis and vertigo attacks

progression.early: Fluctuating low-frequency hearing loss, episodic vertigo
progression.middle: Hearing loss becomes more constant, vertigo attacks may increase
progression.late: Hearing loss permanent and severe, vertigo attacks may decrease ('burnout')

AAO_HNS_2015.definite: 2+ spontaneous vertigo episodes (20min-12hr) + audiometrically documented low-to-medium frequency SNHL + fluctuating aural symptoms (hearing, tinnitus, fullness)

clinical_presentation: Vertigo attacks: rotational, often severe, 20min-12hr, with nausea/vomiting
Hearing loss: low-frequency SNHL; fluctuates early, progresses over time
Tinnitus: typically low-pitched roaring, worse during attacks
Aural fullness: pressure sensation in affected ear

diagnostic_testing.audiometry: Low-frequency SNHL (rising pattern on audiogram early)
diagnostic_testing.vestibular_testing: Caloric testing may show reduced vestibular response (hypofunction)
diagnostic_testing.MRI: Rule out vestibular schwannoma; may show endolymphatic hydrops on delayed gadolinium
diagnostic_testing.ECochG: Electrocochleography - elevated SP/AP ratio supports diagnosis

differential_diagnosis: Vestibular migraine (headache association, longer attacks possible)
Vestibular neuritis (single prolonged attack, no hearing loss)
BPPV (brief attacks, positional, no hearing loss)
Vestibular schwannoma (progressive unilateral hearing loss, MRI diagnostic)
Superior semicircular canal dehiscence (autophony, Tullio phenomenon)

intratympanic.steroids: Dexamethasone for acute attacks and prophylaxis; preserves hearing
intratympanic.gentamicin: Chemical labyrinthectomy; highly effective for vertigo but hearing loss risk

surgical.endolymphatic_sac_surgery: Shunt or decompression; moderate efficacy, preserves function

definition.@value: An inner ear disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, resulting from endolymphatic hydrops

scopeNote.@value: Covers pathophysiology, diagnosis, and management of Meniere disease

learning_objectives: Describe the classic tetrad of Meniere disease symptoms
Explain the pathophysiology of endolymphatic hydrops
Apply AAO-HNS diagnostic criteria for definite Meniere disease
Design stepwise management from lifestyle to surgical interventions
Differentiate Meniere disease from vestibular migraine and other causes
clinical_pearls: EPISODIC vertigo (20min-12hr) distinguishes from BPPV (seconds) and vestibular neuritis (days)
Low-frequency hearing loss early; 'rising' pattern on audiogram
Tinnitus is typically low-pitched ROARING, not high-pitched ringing
Intratympanic gentamicin: very effective for vertigo but may worsen hearing
30-50% eventually develop bilateral disease - counsel patients
common_misconceptions: Meniere's causes constant dizziness - vertigo is EPISODIC with symptom-free intervals
All vertigo with hearing loss is Meniere's - must meet specific criteria
Salt restriction doesn't work - it's actually cornerstone of management
